summary:
A data mining model was applied to analyze Australian Government research grant applications from 2019, aiming to identify innovative project proposals using a Random Forest classifier and unigram features.

Governments use data mining models with feature extraction techniques like Decision Tree or Random Forest classifiers to review research proposals, improving evaluation quality and achieving an accuracy of 84.17%.

Computer science methods for evaluating grant applications include multi-criteria approaches using interval-valued intuitionistic fuzzy sets and Preference Selection Index (PSI), as well as text representation techniques like TF-IDF to adjust term weights.

This section details the workflow of our proposed pipeline and the data mining model. Fig. 1 shows the pipeline of analysing grant applications. 3.1 Data set. The data set used to analyse the grant applications is the 2019 grant applications submitted to an Australian Government research funding agency. 3,805 research proposals are given in this data set with peer-reviewed IC scores (1 - 7). In addition, the entire data set contains different types of grant applications, such as Synergy Grants, Standard Project Grants, and Ideas Grants. Besides the IC score, reviewers also score several other assessment scores, such as “Feasibility Score” or “Significance Score.” Since all research proposals are saved in PDF format, extracting the text from PDF files is necessary. A Metadata Extractor & Loader (MEL) [20] tool is applied to extract text from PDF research proposals and save it in a JSON file with metadata sets and content. By default, all JSON files are stored in CouchDB database [21] based on the proposal index. Before designing the whole pipeline, a statistical analysis is required based on the IC scores of research proposals. At the same time, some fundamental values are also the basis of designing the entire pipeline, such as the median IC score and mode IC score. Table 1 shows a statistic of IC scores, showing that 3,693 research proposals have valid IC scores. In addition, 99 research proposals do not contain an IC score, 13 of which have an IC score below 1.0, and these research proposals therefore not be used in this project. Table 1 also shows the median IC score, 5.0, the most frequent IC score.

3.2 Text pre-processing for grant applications. HaCohen-Kerner et al. [22] proved that text pre-processing techniques could make the model achieve better performance than without the text pre-processing step. After all the text is extracted, all characters, whether uppercase or lowercase, are converted to lowercase. Then, the numbers are also removed because the numbers in the research proposals are not relevant for future analysis. Thirdly, removing punctuations and tokenizing by whitespace are also adopted, which make the text into small pieces called tokens. In addition, the deletion of stop words is one of the most crucial text pre-processing techniques. Fani et al. [23] have shown that deleting stop words can improve the performance of data mining tasks. Therefore, we create a list of custom stop words according to the IDF formula and delete the IDF value of the term from the text lower than 1.0. The reason for choosing 1.0 is that after implementation some preliminary experiments, we confirm that the feature words considered as important by DT and RF classifiers will less than 1000 words. Meanwhile, the words whose IDF value are less than 1.0 only account for 0.2% of the total words, and they are all common words such as “next”, “shift” and “other”. We believe that these words appear too frequently and have no influence on the experimental results. Finally, text stemming is the last technique we apply in the text pre-processing step. Text stemming is a technique for reducing each word to its root format [24]. It helps to reduce the vocabulary and surface syntax to get closer to the meaning of each term, and the Porter Stemming algorithm [25] is implemented in this step.

This section details the workflow of our proposed pipeline and the data mining model. Fig. 1 shows the pipeline of analysing grant applications. 3.1 Data set. The data set used to analyse the grant applications is the 2019 grant applications submitted to an Australian Government research funding agency. 3,805 research proposals are given in this data set with peer-reviewed IC scores (1 - 7). In addition, the entire data set contains different types of grant applications, such as Synergy Grants, Standard Project Grants, and Ideas Grants. Besides the IC score, reviewers also score several other assessment scores, such as “Feasibility Score” or “Significance Score.” Since all research proposals are saved in PDF format, extracting the text from PDF files is necessary. A Metadata Extractor & Loader (MEL) [20] tool is applied to extract text from PDF research proposals and save it in a JSON file with metadata sets and content. By default, all JSON files are stored in CouchDB database [21] based on the proposal index. Before designing the whole pipeline, a statistical analysis is required based on the IC scores of research proposals. At the same time, some fundamental values are also the basis of designing the entire pipeline, such as the median IC score and mode IC score. Table 1 shows a statistic of IC scores, showing that 3,693 research proposals have valid IC scores. In addition, 99 research proposals do not contain an IC score, 13 of which have an IC score below 1.0, and these research proposals therefore not be used in this project. Table 1 also shows the median IC score, 5.0, the most frequent IC score.

3.4 Design and apply the feature extraction technique. We propose a modified TF-IDF algorithm, which only implements the IDF part of TF-IDF as the feature extraction technique. In specific, if the term exists at least once in the documents, specify the IDF value for this term directly. In addition, if a term does not exist in the documents, then the term is assigned a value of 0. The design of this modified feature extraction algorithm follows the idea that rare terms can define innovativeness. The experiment also considers the n-grams [26]. Unigram is the most common choice for text classification tasks, but bigram and trigram may better represent scientific terms, where bigram is two consecutive words in a sentence, and trigram is three consecutive words in a sentence. At the same time, when collecting proposals, we also consider deleting the words that only exist once or twice, because very rare terms tend not to be predictive. In addition, the bigram mentioned in this paper denotes a combination of the unigrams and bigrams. The trigram denotes a combination of the unigrams, bigrams, and trigrams.

3.5 Apply data mining models with grant applications. This paper uses DT and RF classifiers for text classification because we would like to find out the most influential terms and understood how the data mining model predicts high and low IC-score research proposals. The DT and RF classifiers are convenient to present this valuable information. Based on the experimental result of the high and low IC-score research proposals selection, all experiments are conducted with the low IC-score research proposals (IC score 0~15%) and the high IC-score research proposals (IC score 85%~100%). In the comparison study of feature extraction techniques, 400 research proposals for each low and high IC score are randomly selected for model training, and the training data is 85%, and the test data is 15%. In order to analyse the proposed model in the end, the 100 most influential terms from the collections of research proposals are extracted by the function from scikit-learn library [27], which bring us an intuitive understanding of how much each term contributes to reducing the weighted impurities.

3.6 Analyse moderate IC-score grant applications. We also conduct several experiments to analyse moderate IC-score research proposals based on the proposed model. The purpose of this series of experiments is to determine whether there is a relation between proposals with moderate IC scores and that of high and low IC scores. Since the proposed model is trained based on the low IC-score proposals of 0~15% and high IC-score proposals of 85~100%, the range of research proposals with moderate IC score is 15%~85%. Based on the median IC score, the selection range of testing moderate IC score by testing several cut-off options, such as 20, 25, 30, 35, 40, 45, and 50. Table 4 shows a list of experiments used to analyse the research proposals of moderate IC score. Considering the symmetric distribution of the IC scores, new research proposals with low and high IC scores are selected in each experiment, and performance analysis is conducted based on the proposed training model. In addition to the experiments in Table 4, another experiment is designed to check the median IC-score research proposals (IC score = 5.0) to predict the proportion of high or low IC-score research proposals rather than calculate the test accuracy.

This paper uses Python-based methods to extract metadata from various file types using MEL, with statistical analysis involving Numpy and scikit-learn.

The TF-IDF algorithm with a Random Forest (RF) classifier outperforms Decision Tree (DT) under different settings, especially for rare terms related to innovativeness. The best-performing model uses only 99.31% of features and omits bigrams and trigrams.

In summary, a pipeline for analysing grant applications has been proposed with several crucial steps. The proposed data mining model is an RF classifier over documents encoded with features denoting the presence or absence of unigrams. Specifically, the unigram terms are encoded by a modified Term Frequency - Inverse Document Frequency(TF-IDF) algorithm, which only implements the IDF part of TF-IDF. As a result, the proposed model achieves an accuracy of 84.17% based on all types of grant applications. In addition, we also build experiments for Ideas Grants only and “Innovation and Creativity statement” single section.

The future work can be carried out from different perspectives. Firstly, innovation should not be the only evaluation criterion. In order to better evaluate the entire grant application, we should consider other evaluation scores and establish a more comprehensive system that can predict a grant application based on multiple criteria. Secondly, in the future, this project can also apply some other effective data mining models, such as SVM, AdaBoost, and Xgboost. In addition, the pre-trained language models in the Natural Language Processing (NLP) field perform well in understanding text semantics, which can also be our next research focus. Thirdly, our proposed method cannot predict future grant applications because the current data set contains only key terms for 2019 and does not represent future grant applications. Therefore, it is an important research topic to consider building a long-term data mining model to predict future grant applications.

Predicate-transform.label: transform
Predicate-transform.description: To convert or change something from one form to another, often involving a significant alteration or reorganization. This predicate indicates that the subject has taken an object and changed its nature, structure, or appearance.

Predicate-reveal.label: reveal
Predicate-reveal.description: To reveal means to uncover or disclose previously unknown or hidden information about a subject, making it accessible and understandable. The predicate 'reveal' connects the subject (the source of the information) with the object (the insights, trends, and patterns that are uncovered), indicating a process of discovery, analysis, and presentation.

Predicate-applied_to.label: applied to
Predicate-applied_to.description: The predicate 'applied to' indicates a relationship where the subject (a concept or method) is used, implemented, or put into practice for the purpose of analyzing, processing, or manipulating the object. The connection between the subject and object suggests that the subject's capabilities are being leveraged to achieve some outcome or insight related to the object.

Predicate-is_interested_in_understanding.label: is interested in understanding
Predicate-is_interested_in_understanding.description: Expresses a desire to comprehend or grasp the meaning, significance, or essence of something. This predicate indicates that the subject has a curiosity-driven motivation to explore and learn about the object, seeking insight into its nature, purpose, or implications.

Predicate-are_studied.label: are studied
Predicate-are_studied.description: The predicate 'are studied' indicates a relationship of academic inquiry or investigation between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject (Data mining models, in this case) are being examined, analyzed, or explored with respect to the object (feature encoding algorithms), which may involve theoretical or practical applications.

Predicate-over.label: over
Predicate-over.description: The predicate 'over' indicates a relationship where the subject has control or influence over the object. It suggests that the subject's scope, domain, or jurisdiction extends to cover or encompass the object.

Predicate-are_encoded_by.label: are encoded by
Predicate-are_encoded_by.description: The predicate 'are encoded by' indicates a relationship where the subject (a set of linguistic units, such as words or phrases) has its meaning, structure, or characteristics represented or transformed into another form or representation described by the object. This transformation can involve various processes like encoding, compression, abstraction, or simplification.

Predicate-only_implements_the_IDF_part_o.label: only implements the IDF part of
Predicate-only_implements_the_IDF_part_o.description: This predicate indicates that the subject is a simplified or reduced version of the object, retaining only the part related to inverse document frequency (IDF) and discarding any other aspects. The connection between the subject and object suggests a transformation from a more comprehensive concept (the object) to a focused representation (the subject), highlighting the importance of IDF in this context.

Predicate-presents.label: presents
Predicate-presents.description: The predicate 'presents' indicates that the subject provides or offers something to someone else, often with the intention of sharing knowledge, ideas, or solutions. It implies a sense of introduction, revelation, or unveiling, where the subject brings forth the object as a valuable contribution.

Predicate-prove.label: prove
Predicate-prove.description: To prove a predicate connects the subject to evidence or demonstration that supports or confirms the truth of the object. It implies providing logical and convincing arguments or facts that establish the validity, accuracy, or existence of something.

Predicate-requires.label: requires
Predicate-requires.description: The predicate 'requires' indicates a necessary condition or essential element that must be present in order for something to exist, happen, or be achieved. It implies a sense of necessity, obligation, or expectation between the subject and object.

Predicate-is_self-evident_for_every_coun.label: is self-evident for every country
Predicate-is_self-evident_for_every_coun.description: The predicate 'is self-evident for every country' indicates a universal truth or obvious fact that applies to all countries. It suggests that the subject (developing cutting-edge scientific research, etc.) is inherently true and widely accepted by everyone across different nations.

Predicate-developing_cutting-edge_scient.label: developing cutting-edge scientific research is self-evident for
Predicate-developing_cutting-edge_scient.description: The predicate 'developing cutting-edge scientific research is self-evident for' indicates a connection between the subject and object where the development of advanced scientific inquiry is inherently justified or expected by the object. This relationship suggests that the object provides the context, motivation, or justification for the pursuit of innovative scientific discoveries.

Predicate-provide.label: provide
Predicate-provide.description: To provide means to offer or make available something (e.g. resources, support, information) that can be used by someone else for a specific purpose or goal.

Predicate-evaluate.label: evaluate
Predicate-evaluate.description: To assess or judge the quality, value, or significance of something based on certain criteria or standards. The subject evaluates the object by examining its characteristics, merits, and demerits to form an opinion about it.

Predicate-is.label: is
Predicate-is.description: The predicate 'is' connects the subject to an attribute or characteristic that defines its nature, essence, or identity. It establishes a state of being between the subject and object, indicating that they share a common property or quality.

Predicate-write.label: write
Predicate-write.description: To create or produce written content, such as text, documents, reports, or proposals, using various forms of expression like language, symbols, and codes. The predicate 'write' connects the subject to a tangible outcome that represents their thoughts, ideas, or findings.

Predicate-present.label: present
Predicate-present.description: The predicate 'present' indicates that the subject (e.g. scientists and researchers) are currently engaged with or showcasing something about themselves, such as their ideas, plans, or work. It suggests a sense of immediacy, relevance, and visibility.

Predicate-explain.label: explain
Predicate-explain.description: To explain means to clarify or interpret the meaning of something (the object), typically by providing a logical or rational account that connects it to other concepts, ideas, or experiences. The subject, in this case scientists and researchers, are responsible for rendering the object comprehensible, often through the use of evidence-based reasoning, analogies, examples, or other forms of explanation.

Predicate-are_increasingly_using_data_mi.label: are increasingly using data mining models to assist in the manual review of
Predicate-are_increasingly_using_data_mi.description: This predicate indicates that an entity (the subject) employs a specific method or approach (data mining models) to facilitate and improve their process of reviewing or evaluating something else (the object). The increasing use suggests a growing reliance on these data-driven methods, which may imply advancements in technology, efficiency gains, or enhanced decision-making capabilities.

Predicate-receive.label: receive
Predicate-receive.description: To receive indicates a subject's acquisition or acceptance of something from an external source. The predicate establishes a relationship between the subject and object, suggesting that the subject has obtained or taken possession of the object.

Predicate-review.label: review
Predicate-review.description: To review means to examine and evaluate the quality or validity of something, typically in a critical manner. The subject (in this case, expert panels) applies their expertise and judgment to assess the object (research proposal), providing an informed opinion on its strengths, weaknesses, and overall value.

Predicate-receive_thousands_of_research_.label: receive thousands of research proposals each year, which are reviewed only by
Predicate-receive_thousands_of_research_.description: This predicate indicates that a subject entity regularly receives a large quantity of research proposal submissions from various sources. The proposals are then evaluated and assessed solely by the object entity, which has expertise or authority to review them.

Predicate-are_using.label: are using
Predicate-are_using.description: The predicate 'are using' indicates a relationship of application or implementation between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject (in this case, government research funding agencies) has adopted, employed, or incorporated the object (Data mining models) as part of their operations, processes, or practices.

Predicate-better_screen.label: better screen
Predicate-better_screen.description: The predicate 'better screen' indicates that a subject has improved or enhanced an object's quality, relevance, or effectiveness through some form of evaluation, filtering, or selection process.

Predicate-can_help.label: can help
Predicate-can_help.description: The predicate 'can help' indicates a potential assistance or support relationship between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject has the ability to render aid, guidance, or expertise to the object, which may be individuals, groups, organizations, or even abstract entities.

Predicate-can_be_applied_to_develop.label: can be applied to develop
Predicate-can_be_applied_to_develop.description: The predicate 'can be applied to develop' indicates that the subject has a potential or capacity to contribute to the creation of something new (the object), often by providing insights, guidance, or frameworks. In general, this predicate suggests a relationship where the subject serves as a foundation or starting point for developing the object.

Predicate-establish.label: establish
Predicate-establish.description: To establish means to create and set up a new entity, process, or system that did not previously exist. This predicate indicates the subject's intentional action of bringing something into being, often with a sense of permanence or stability.

Predicate-can_better_understand_how_to_e.label: can better understand how to ensure that
Predicate-can_better_understand_how_to_e.description: This predicate indicates a relationship where the subject has the capacity or ability to comprehend and grasp the object's requirements for ensuring something. The subject can develop an understanding of how to guarantee that the object achieves its goals, meets its needs, or maintains certain standards.

Predicate-respond_to.label: respond to
Predicate-respond_to.description: The predicate 'respond to' indicates a relationship where the subject (e.g. human evaluators) exhibits or demonstrates a reaction, behavior, or characteristic that corresponds to or matches the object (e.g. these necessary qualities). This connection implies an evaluation, assessment, or judgment made by the subject in response to the object's presence, characteristics, or attributes.

Predicate-apply.label: apply
Predicate-apply.description: To utilize or put into practice a specific method, approach, or strategy to achieve a particular outcome. The predicate 'apply' indicates that the subject (Data mining models) uses or employs the object (feature extraction technique) for a certain purpose.

Predicate-predict.label: predict
Predicate-predict.description: To predict means to form an expectation or estimation about a future event or outcome based on available information and analysis. The subject of the predicate, typically a model, algorithm, or system, uses its capabilities and knowledge to generate a forecast or projection that describes the object, which can be a phenomenon, pattern, or set of data.

Predicate-assign.label: assign
Predicate-assign.description: To assign means to allocate or designate something (in this case, IC scores) for a specific purpose or context. The predicate 'assign' establishes a connection between the subject and object by indicating that the subject has taken control of the object's value, meaning, or function.

Predicate-predicts.label: predicts
Predicate-predicts.description: The predicate 'predicts' indicates a causal relationship between the subject and object, suggesting that the subject (typically an entity capable of making predictions or generating outputs) produces or generates the object as its expected outcome. In general, this predicate implies a forward-looking or anticipatory aspect, where the subject's capabilities are used to forecast or anticipate the occurrence of something.

Predicate-is_to_develop_and_understand_h.label: is to develop and understand how the model inferred research proposals with high IC scores from the data features.
Predicate-is_to_develop_and_understand_h.description: This predicate describes a process of analyzing or interpreting the output of a machine learning model, specifically how it inferred research proposals with high IC scores from given data features. It connects the subject (e.g., project) to the object (e.g., predictive vocabulary for contemporaneous proposals) by indicating that the subject is responsible for understanding and developing insights from the model's outputs.

Predicate-develops.label: develops
Predicate-develops.description: The predicate 'develops' indicates a process of growth or maturation, where the subject (a person, organization, or entity) creates, improves, or refines something new or existing. The object represents the outcome or result of this development process.

Predicate-inferred.label: inferred
Predicate-inferred.description: The predicate 'inferred' indicates that a conclusion or interpretation has been drawn based on available information. It suggests that the subject (project, in this case) has derived or deduced some insight from the object (research proposals with high IC scores from data features), possibly through analysis, reasoning, or pattern recognition.

Predicate-choose.label: choose
Predicate-choose.description: The predicate 'choose' represents a selection or decision-making process that connects the subject to one or more options. It indicates that the subject has selected or opted for one of the possible alternatives, which are represented by the object.

Predicate-are_listed_as_follows.label: are listed as follows
Predicate-are_listed_as_follows.description: This predicate indicates a relationship where the subject (a collection or set of items) has its constituent parts or elements presented in a specific order, which is described by the object. The phrase 'are listed as follows' serves to introduce and organize the subsequent presentation of these constituents.

Predicate-has_a.label: has a
Predicate-has_a.description: The predicate 'has a' indicates possession or association between two entities. It implies that the subject entity possesses, contains, or is related to the object entity in some way.

Predicate-proposed_with.label: proposed with
Predicate-proposed_with.description: The predicate 'proposed with' indicates a relationship where the subject (e.g., an idea, concept, or approach) has been paired or associated with another entity (the object), often for the purpose of evaluation, consideration, or implementation. This connection suggests that the two entities have been brought together to facilitate further development, testing, or refinement.

Predicate-uses.label: uses
Predicate-uses.description: The predicate 'uses' indicates a relationship where the subject entity employs, utilizes, or exploits the object to achieve some purpose, perform an action, or accomplish a task.

Predicate-denotes.label: denotes
Predicate-denotes.description: The predicate 'denotes' indicates a relationship between its subject and object where the subject represents or signifies the meaning or existence of the object. In general, it suggests that the subject serves as an indicator, representation, or manifestation of the object's characteristics, properties, or concepts.

Predicate-is_divided_into.label: is divided into
Predicate-is_divided_into.description: The predicate 'is divided into' indicates a partitioning or segmentation of the subject into distinct parts or categories, as specified by the object. It implies that the subject has been organized or structured according to some criteria, and the resulting divisions are reflected in the object.

Predicate-describes.label: describes
Predicate-describes.description: The predicate 'describes' connects a subject (typically an entity or concept) to its detailed explanation or representation. It indicates that the object provides a comprehensive overview, outline, or account of the subject's characteristics, features, or nature.

Predicate-brings.label: brings
Predicate-brings.description: The predicate 'brings' indicates a relationship where the subject (a person or entity) contributes to or introduces something new into existence, often in a creative or innovative manner. The object represents what is being brought forth, which can be an idea, concept, design, or other tangible outcome.

Predicate-are_introduced_in_this_section.label: are introduced in this section about
Predicate-are_introduced_in_this_section.description: This predicate indicates a connection between the subject and object by providing context or background information that relates to the topic of discussion. It suggests that the subject (experimental settings in this case) will be explored or examined within the scope defined by the object (hardware platforms), which provides a framework for understanding the significance or relevance of the subject.

Predicate-gives.label: gives
Predicate-gives.description: Indicates a transfer of possession or control from the subject to the object. The predicate 'gives' implies that the subject has authority over the object and is intentionally transferring it, its value, or its significance to someone else.

Predicate-proposed.label: proposed
Predicate-proposed.description: To propose means to suggest or recommend something as a solution, method, or idea. It implies that the subject has put forward an option for consideration and evaluation by others.

Predicate-based_on.label: based on
Predicate-based_on.description: The predicate 'based on' indicates a relationship where the subject relies on or derives its characteristics, properties, or conclusions from the object. The connection between the subject and object suggests that the subject's nature, validity, or relevance are grounded in or supported by the information, principles, or methods provided by the object.

Predicate-was_used_to_determine.label: was used to determine
Predicate-was_used_to_determine.description: This predicate indicates that the subject played a role in establishing or identifying the object. The subject served as a means or tool for determining the characteristics, properties, or values represented by the object.

Predicate-determine.label: determine
Predicate-determine.description: To determine means to establish or decide upon a specific characteristic, attribute, or value that defines or quantifies the relationship between the subject and object. It implies an act of discovery, inference, or calculation that yields a clear understanding or measurement of the object's nature or significance.

Predicate-used_a.label: used a
Predicate-used_a.description: The predicate 'used a' indicates that the subject has employed or applied an object to achieve some purpose, solve a problem, or accomplish a task. The connection between the subject and object suggests a relationship of utilization, where the subject leverages the object's capabilities or properties to attain its goals.

Predicate-to_extract_representative_keyw.label: to extract representative keywords from the abstract of each paper [5]
Predicate-to_extract_representative_keyw.description: This predicate connects a linguistic analysis method (subject) with an action that identifies key concepts or phrases in written summaries (abstracts) of research papers, yielding representative keywords. The connection highlights the subject's ability to extract meaningful information from abstracts.

Predicate-extract_representative_keyword.label: extract representative keywords from the abstract of each paper
Predicate-extract_representative_keyword.description: The predicate 'extract representative keywords from the abstract of each paper' connects a subject (typically an entity or system) to its object by describing the action of identifying and selecting key terms that summarize the main ideas in the abstracts of multiple papers. This connection enables the subject to analyze, categorize, or utilize these extracted keywords for further processing or decision-making.

Predicate-was_used_to_group_papers_with_.label: was used to group papers with similar topics based on
Predicate-was_used_to_group_papers_with_.description: This predicate indicates that a specific method or technique (the subject) was employed as an analytical tool to categorize and organize entities (papers with similar topics based on the object), typically for purposes of analysis, comparison, or understanding.

Predicate-showed_that.label: showed that
Predicate-showed_that.description: Indicates a conclusion or inference drawn from evidence presented by the subject. The predicate 'showed that' connects the subject (the source of information) to the object (a statement, finding, or insight), implying that the subject's presentation provides sufficient grounds for accepting the truth of the object.

Predicate-and.label: and
Predicate-and.description: The predicate 'and' connects the subject to the object by indicating a relationship of conjunction or combination. It suggests that the subject and object are related in some way, often implying equivalence, similarity, or co-occurrence.

Predicate-used_in.label: used in
Predicate-used_in.description: The predicate 'used in' indicates a relationship where the subject (a concept or technique) is applied to or employed within the context of the object (an activity, field, or domain).

Predicate-adjusts.label: adjusts
Predicate-adjusts.description: The predicate 'adjusts' indicates a process of modifying or refining something to achieve a desired state. It implies an intentional action taken by the subject (the IDF, for example) to modify or correct the object (term weights in documents), resulting in a more accurate, precise, or optimal outcome.

Predicate-was_proposed_based_on.label: was proposed based on
Predicate-was_proposed_based_on.description: The predicate 'was proposed based on' indicates a relationship between an idea or concept (the subject) and its underlying foundation or inspiration (the object). It suggests that the subject was developed, created, or justified using the principles, methods, or ideas represented by the object. In general, this predicate highlights the connection between a solution or approach and the theoretical or empirical basis upon which it is grounded.

Predicate-performed_better_than.label: performed better than
Predicate-performed_better_than.description: Indicates a comparison between two entities or methods where one entity or method surpasses another's performance, quality, or effectiveness.

Predicate-used.label: used
Predicate-used.description: The predicate 'used' indicates that the subject has employed or utilized the object for a specific purpose. It suggests an intentional action of making use of something, which can imply a range of meanings depending on the context.

Predicate-proposed_a_text_sentiment_clas.label: proposed a text sentiment classification technique based on
Predicate-proposed_a_text_sentiment_clas.description: This predicate indicates that the subject has developed and presented a specific text sentiment classification technique, which relies on or utilizes the object as its foundation. The connection between the subject and object suggests an intellectual contribution, where the subject has created or proposed a novel approach to text sentiment analysis based on the underlying principles or methods described by the object.

Predicate-proposed_a_text_sentiment_clas.label: proposed a text sentiment classification technique based on the TF-IDF algorithm
Predicate-proposed_a_text_sentiment_clas.description: This predicate describes an act of proposing or suggesting a specific approach to classify the sentiment of text data. The proposed technique relies on the TF-IDF algorithm, which connects the subject (the person or entity making the proposal) with the object (the classification technique itself).

Predicate-was_proposed_for.label: was proposed for
Predicate-was_proposed_for.description: The predicate 'was proposed for' indicates a relationship between an idea or concept (the subject) and its intended application or purpose (the object). It suggests that someone has suggested using the subject to achieve or solve something related to the object, implying a potential solution or approach.

Predicate-are.label: are
Predicate-are.description: The predicate 'are' indicates a relationship of equivalence or identity between the subject and object, suggesting that they share a common characteristic, quantity, or value.

Predicate-was.label: was
Predicate-was.description: The predicate 'was' indicates a relationship of existence or identity between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject has been associated with, characterized by, or equivalent to the state or condition described by the object.

Predicate-can_be_interpreted_to_mean_tha.label: can be interpreted to mean that
Predicate-can_be_interpreted_to_mean_tha.description: This predicate indicates a possible or plausible interpretation of the subject with respect to the object. It suggests that there exists an underlying meaning or significance between the subject and the object, which can be inferred or understood in a particular way.

Predicate-means_that_each_classifier_in_.label: mean[s] that each classifier in the ensemble is a DT classifier, while all combinations of classifiers are a forest
Predicate-means_that_each_classifier_in_.description: This predicate establishes a connection between a subject (e.g., 'forest') and an object (e.g., 'DT classifier'), indicating that the subject's constituent parts or characteristics are described by the object. In this case, each classifier in the ensemble being referred to as a DT classifier is what defines the nature of the forest.

Predicate-depends_independently_on.label: depends independently on
Predicate-depends_independently_on.description: The predicate 'depends independently on' indicates that the subject has an autonomous relationship with the object, where its existence or behavior does not rely on any external factors or dependencies. The connection between the subject and object is direct and self-contained.

Predicate-votes.label: votes
Predicate-votes.description: To vote means to express a choice or preference among available options. The subject of this predicate represents an entity that makes a selection from a set of possibilities, and the object refers to the thing being chosen or preferred.

Predicate-selects.label: selects
Predicate-selects.description: The predicate 'selects' indicates a process of choosing or identifying one option from among multiple possibilities, resulting in a specific outcome that connects the subject to the object. It implies a deliberate and intentional action by the subject to determine the object as the preferred choice.

Predicate-are_welcome_for_its_advantage_.label: are welcome for its advantage of showing how models make decisions according to the data features
Predicate-are_welcome_for_its_advantage_.description: This predicate describes a relationship where the subject (e.g., Data mining models) has an inherent quality or characteristic that allows it to be considered suitable for its ability to demonstrate how decisions are made based on specific data features. The object (e.g., DT classifier) is likely related to this process, potentially being one of the decision-making methods or techniques used by the subject.

Predicate-compared.label: compared
Predicate-compared.description: The predicate 'compared' indicates a relationship where the subject (in this case, five data mining classifiers) has been evaluated or examined with respect to another entity, concept, or value represented by the object. The comparison can be implicit or explicit, and may involve various aspects such as similarity, difference, ranking, or evaluation.

Predicate-implemented_with.label: implemented with
Predicate-implemented_with.description: The predicate 'implemented with' indicates a relationship between an entity (the subject) and a method or approach used to develop or create that entity. The object represents the specific technique, framework, tool, or strategy employed to implement the subject.

Predicate-applied.label: applied
Predicate-applied.description: The predicate 'applied' indicates that a method or technique (subject) was used to implement or utilize another concept or approach (object), often resulting in some practical application, analysis, or solution.

Predicate-were_compared_with.label: were compared with
Predicate-were_compared_with.description: Indicates a comparison or evaluation of two entities (subject and object), suggesting that their characteristics, properties, or performance are being assessed against each other.

Predicate-was_compared.label: was compared
Predicate-was_compared.description: Indicates that two or more entities were evaluated and contrasted with each other to determine their relative merits, strengths, or differences.

Predicate-classified_by.label: classified by
Predicate-classified_by.description: The predicate 'classified by' indicates a relationship where the subject (a set of entities or data points) has been categorized, grouped, or assigned to specific categories based on characteristics extracted from it using the object (an algorithm, model, or method).

Predicate-were_used.label: were used
Predicate-were_used.description: Indicates that a subject (typically an algorithm, method or technique) was employed to process, analyze or manipulate the object (which can be data, text, images, etc.) in order to achieve some goal or produce certain results.

Predicate-details.label: details
Predicate-details.description: The predicate 'details' connects a subject to an object by providing specific information or explanations about what the object represents. It implies that the subject has certain characteristics, features, or aspects that are being described in more detail.

Predicate-shows.label: shows
Predicate-shows.description: The predicate 'shows' indicates a relationship where the subject (in this case, Fig. 1) presents or displays information about the object (the pipeline of analysing grant applications), often in a visual or illustrative manner.

Predicate-used_to_analyse_the_grant_appl.label: used to analyse the grant applications is
Predicate-used_to_analyse_the_grant_appl.description: The predicate 'used to analyze the grant applications' indicates a historical or past purpose of the subject (data sets, in this case), which was to examine and evaluate grant proposals. This connection highlights that the data sets were designed or intended for analyzing grant applications at some point in time.

Predicate-are_given_in_this_data_set_wit.label: are given in this data set with peer-reviewed IC scores
Predicate-are_given_in_this_data_set_wit.description: The predicate 'are given in this data set with peer-reviewed IC scores' indicates that a collection of items (subject) contains or provides information about a specific type of scoring system, specifically IC scores ranging from 1 to 7. The object represents the entity being described, which is typically a dataset containing research proposals.

Predicate-includes.label: includes
Predicate-includes.description: Indicates that a subject contains or comprises one or more objects. The predicate 'includes' establishes a relationship of containment or membership between the subject and object(s), suggesting that the subject has as its parts, components, or elements the listed object(s).

Predicate-besides.label: besides
Predicate-besides.description: The predicate 'besides' indicates a supplementary or additional relationship between the subject and object. It suggests that the object (reviewers scoring several other assessment scores, in this case) is not exhaustive of all possible alternatives, but rather one among many others.

Predicate-scored_as.label: scored as
Predicate-scored_as.description: The predicate 'scored as' indicates a mapping or correspondence between two scores or values. It suggests that one score (the subject) has been assigned, categorized, or evaluated according to another standard or reference point (the object).

Predicate-are_saved_in.label: are saved in
Predicate-are_saved_in.description: The predicate 'are saved in' indicates a relationship of storage or containment between the subject and object. It suggests that the information or data represented by the subject (in this case, research proposals) are physically stored or held within the format or medium specified as the object (PDF).

Predicate-saved_in.label: saved in
Predicate-saved_in.description: The predicate 'saved in' indicates a relationship where the subject (in this case, all research proposals) are stored or contained within the object (PDF files), suggesting a physical or digital repository for storing and preserving information.

Predicate-extracts.label: extracts
Predicate-extracts.description: The predicate 'extracts' indicates a process of obtaining or pulling out specific information from a source (object) by an entity (subject). This can involve identifying, isolating, and/or retrieving relevant data points, patterns, or structures from the object.

Predicate-is_based_on.label: is based on
Predicate-is_based_on.description: The predicate 'is based on' indicates a relationship where the subject relies on or derives its foundation from the object. It suggests that the subject is grounded in, supported by, or has its validity established through reference to the object.

Predicate-shows_a_statistic_of.label: shows a statistic of
Predicate-shows_a_statistic_of.description: The predicate 'shows a statistic of' indicates that the subject (a table or other data presentation) displays and presents information about the object (a statistical measure), providing context for understanding its meaning, significance, or relevance.

Predicate-have_valid_IC_scores.label: have valid IC scores
Predicate-have_valid_IC_scores.description: The predicate 'have valid IC scores' indicates that a subject (e.g., research proposal) possesses or meets certain standards of quality or relevance as measured by International Classification (IC) scoring, which connects the subject to a specific quantity or number of proposals that meet these criteria.

Predicate-have.label: have
Predicate-have.description: The predicate 'have' indicates a relationship between the subject and object where the subject possesses or holds the described property or characteristic denoted by the object. This can include possession, ownership, existence, or having some quality or attribute.

Predicate-is_for.label: is for
Predicate-is_for.description: The predicate 'is for' indicates a purpose or intention behind an action or process. It suggests that the subject (action or process) serves to achieve, facilitate, or support the object (goal or objective). In general, it implies a causal relationship between the subject and object, where the subject is intended to bring about or contribute to the realization of the object.

Predicate-are_deleted_by.label: are deleted by
Predicate-are_deleted_by.description: The predicate 'are deleted by' indicates a causal relationship between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject (in this case, stop words) has its existence or significance diminished or removed as a result of an external factor represented by the object (the deletion of stop words). The predicate highlights the agency responsible for the elimination or reduction of the subject's presence.

Predicate-can_improve.label: can improve
Predicate-can_improve.description: The predicate 'can improve' indicates a potential enhancement or upgrading relationship between the subject and object. It suggests that the action performed by the subject has the capacity to positively impact or enhance the state, quality, or performance of the object.

Predicate-according_to.label: according to
Predicate-according_to.description: The predicate 'according to' indicates a relationship of authority or basis for information between the subject and object. It suggests that the truth or accuracy of the subject's description, definition, or classification is grounded in or justified by the object.

Predicate-chooses.label: chooses
Predicate-chooses.description: Indicates a deliberate selection or preference for something by the subject, often implying agency and intentionality.

Predicate-have_no_influence_on.label: have no influence on
Predicate-have_no_influence_on.description: The predicate 'have no influence on' indicates a lack of causal relationship between the subject and object. It suggests that any changes or effects observed in the object are not caused by, or dependent upon, the subject.

Predicate-is_implemented_in.label: is implemented in
Predicate-is_implemented_in.description: Indicates that a process or method (subject) uses a specific tool, technique, or framework (object) to achieve its purpose. This predicate highlights the relationship between an abstract concept and its concrete implementation.

Predicate-specify.label: specify
Predicate-specify.description: The predicate 'specify' connects the subject (a term or concept) to a specific characteristic, attribute, or measurement that defines its nature. It indicates that the object (IDF value, in this case) provides further detail about the subject's properties.

Predicate-follows.label: follows
Predicate-follows.description: Indicates a logical or causal connection between two concepts, where the subject is derived from, based on, or consistent with the object. The predicate 'follows' suggests that there is an underlying relationship of consequence, implication, or inspiration between the subject and the object.

Predicate-defines.label: defines
Predicate-defines.description: The predicate 'defines' indicates a relationship where the subject provides a clear and specific meaning or scope for the object. It implies that the subject establishes, outlines, or determines the nature of the object, often by setting boundaries, parameters, or criteria.

Predicate-mentions.label: mentions
Predicate-mentions.description: The predicate 'mentions' indicates that the subject refers to or alludes to the object, highlighting its significance, relevance, or connection.

Predicate-apply_with.label: apply with
Predicate-apply_with.description: To use or implement a subject's capabilities to achieve a specific outcome or goal described by the object. The predicate 'apply with' indicates that the subject is being utilized as a means to accomplish something, often involving a process of transformation, analysis, or evaluation.

Predicate-would_like_to_find_out.label: would like to find out
Predicate-would_like_to_find_out.description: The predicate 'would like to find out' indicates a desire for knowledge or information about something. It expresses an interest in discovering or learning more about the object, which can be a concept, phenomenon, fact, or other type of data. Predicate-compared_in_a_study.label: compared in a study
Predicate-compared_in_a_study.description: The predicate 'compared in a study' indicates that the subject (a feature extraction technique) was evaluated and analyzed within the context of a specific research investigation or experiment, as described by the object (comparison study).

Predicate-used_as_training_data.label: used as training data
Predicate-used_as_training_data.description: Indicates that a dataset or collection of data serves as input for training a machine learning model. This predicate connects the subject (the dataset) to the object (model training), implying that the former is utilized in some way to develop, refine, or validate the latter.

Predicate-are_used_as.label: are used as
Predicate-are_used_as.description: The predicate 'are used as' indicates a relationship where the subject (in this case, some entity or entities) serves a specific purpose or function for the object. The object represents the context in which the subject's properties or characteristics are utilized.

Predicate-conduct.label: conduct
Predicate-conduct.description: To conduct means to perform or execute a specific action, process, or activity with the intention of achieving a particular outcome. It implies taking control and being actively involved in bringing about the object's existence, occurrence, or realization.

Predicate-analyse.label: analyse
Predicate-analyse.description: To examine or investigate a subject in order to identify patterns, relationships, or underlying structures. The predicate 'analyse' implies a systematic and often detailed examination of the object, with the goal of gaining insight, understanding, or making informed decisions.

Predicate-have_a_relation_to.label: have a relation to
Predicate-have_a_relation_to.description: Indicates a connection or association between two entities, concepts, or categories. The predicate suggests that there exists some kind of relationship, similarity, or correspondence between the subject and object.

Predicate-is_trained_based_on.label: is trained based on
Predicate-is_trained_based_on.description: The predicate 'is trained based on' indicates that the subject has been developed or learned from the object. It suggests a causal relationship between the two, implying that the subject's knowledge, skills, or behavior is influenced by the information, data, or principles provided by the object.

Predicate-covers.label: covers
Predicate-covers.description: The predicate 'covers' indicates a relationship where the subject represents or encompasses the object. This can imply that the subject provides an overview, includes, or has jurisdiction over the object.

Predicate-by_testing.label: by testing
Predicate-by_testing.description: The predicate 'by testing' indicates a method or approach used to determine or evaluate something (the subject), which involves examining or analyzing various options or alternatives (the object).

Predicate-are_designed_to_check.label: are designed to check
Predicate-are_designed_to_check.description: The predicate 'are designed to check' indicates a purpose or intention behind an action (subject), which is to verify or validate something (object). It implies that the subject has been created, developed, or intended for the specific goal of checking or evaluating the object.

Predicate-predicts_the_proportion_of_hig.label: predicts the proportion of high or low
Predicate-predicts_the_proportion_of_hig.description: This predicate indicates that the subject (in this case, an IC score with a value of 5.0) has some relationship to determining or estimating the proportion of instances that fall into one of two categories: high or low. The object (research proposal) likely represents the context in which this prediction is being made, such as a study design or methodology.

Predicate-selecting.label: selecting
Predicate-selecting.description: The predicate 'selecting' indicates a process of choosing or picking out specific entities from a larger set, based on certain criteria. It implies that the subject (in this case, experiments) is actively engaging with the object (proposals), evaluating and identifying those that meet specific conditions.

Predicate-implementing.label: implementing
Predicate-implementing.description: The predicate 'implementing' indicates that a subject (in this case, data mining models) uses or employs an object (Decision Tree (DT) and RF classifiers), likely as part of its functionality or methodology. It suggests a relationship where the subject incorporates or relies on the object to achieve some goal or outcome.

Predicate-applied_to_implement.label: applied to implement
Predicate-applied_to_implement.description: The predicate 'applied to implement' indicates that a specific technique or framework (subject) was used as the foundation for developing or creating something new (object). This connection implies that the subject's capabilities, tools, and methodologies were leveraged to bring the object into existence.

Predicate-adopted_as_one_of_the.label: adopted as one of the
Predicate-adopted_as_one_of_the.description: This predicate indicates a classification or categorization relationship between the subject and object. The subject (in this case, RF classifiers) is assigned to a specific category or group among others (Data mining models), implying that it shares characteristics or properties with other members of that category.

Predicate-is_used_to_implement.label: is used to implement
Predicate-is_used_to_implement.description: This predicate indicates that a subject (a tool or framework) serves as the means by which an object (an algorithm, technique, or concept) is put into practice. The relationship between the subject and object implies a functional connection where the subject provides the necessary infrastructure for implementing the object.

Predicate-is_a_significant_step_in_apply.label: is a significant step in applying
Predicate-is_a_significant_step_in_apply.description: This predicate indicates that the subject represents an important or crucial action within the process of applying the object. It highlights the significance of the subject as a necessary step in achieving the goal represented by the object.

Predicate-define_the_data_mining_model.label: define the data mining model
Predicate-define_the_data_mining_model.description: To 'define the data mining model' means to specify or determine a particular approach or framework for extracting valuable patterns, relationships, or insights from a dataset. This predicate connects the subject (the step in the process) with the object (a specific type of classifier and its parameters), indicating that this is the point at which the chosen method is formally established.

Predicate-need_to_implement.label: need to implement
Predicate-need_to_implement.description: To indicate a requirement or obligation for the subject to take action and put into practice or utilize something (the object), typically in order to achieve a specific goal or solve a problem.

Predicate-defined_for.label: defined for
Predicate-defined_for.description: The predicate 'defined for' indicates a relationship between the subject and object where the subject specifies or determines the scope or range within which the object applies, operates, or has meaning.

Predicate-make.label: make
Predicate-make.description: The predicate 'make' indicates a causal relationship between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject has an influence on or brings about the state described by the object, often implying a transformation or creation of something.

Predicate-on.label: on
Predicate-on.description: The predicate 'on' indicates a relationship of dependence or operation between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject is acting upon, operating within, or being performed on the object.

Predicate-values_for_each_accuracy_are_l.label: values for each accuracy are listed
Predicate-values_for_each_accuracy_are_l.description: This predicate indicates that a list of values corresponding to different levels of accuracy (or precision) has been provided. Predicate-are_listed.label: are listed
Predicate-are_listed.description: Indicates a relationship where the subject is comprised or categorized into distinct items that can be referred to by name or description. The predicate 'are listed' implies an organized and structured presentation of the subject, often in a hierarchical or sequential manner.

Predicate-indicates.label: indicates
Predicate-indicates.description: Indicates connects a subject to an object by specifying or pointing out its meaning, significance, or relationship. It implies that the subject provides evidence, suggests, or reveals information about the object.

Predicate-applied_in.label: applied in
Predicate-applied_in.description: The predicate 'applied in' indicates that a specific technique or methodology (subject) was used to achieve or accomplish something (object), typically within a particular context, domain, or field.

Predicate-evaluate_the_performance_of.label: evaluate the performance of
Predicate-evaluate_the_performance_of.description: To assess and determine the effectiveness or quality of something in achieving its intended purpose or goals, typically by comparing actual results to expected outcomes.

Predicate-has.label: has
Predicate-has.description: The predicate 'has' indicates a possession or attribution relationship between the subject and object, suggesting that the subject possesses, contains, or is characterized by the described attribute or property.

Predicate-used_to_find.label: used to find
Predicate-used_to_find.description: The predicate 'used to find' indicates a purpose or intention behind an action or process. It describes how something (the subject) was employed, utilized, or applied in order to achieve or discover the object.

Predicate-combines.label: combines
Predicate-combines.description: The predicate 'combines' indicates a relationship where two or more entities (represented by the subject and object) are brought together to form a new whole, often resulting in a unified concept, method, or approach. This connection implies that the subject entity is capable of integrating or merging its properties with those of the object entity to create something novel.

Predicate-used_with.label: used with
Predicate-used_with.description: The predicate 'used with' indicates a relationship between two entities where one entity (the subject) is employed or applied together with another entity (the object), often to achieve a specific purpose, solve a problem, or accomplish a task. This connection implies that the subject and object are used in conjunction to produce a particular outcome.

Predicate-can_consistently_achieve_bette.label: can consistently achieve better performance than
Predicate-can_consistently_achieve_bette.description: This predicate indicates a comparative relationship between two entities or systems (subject and object), suggesting that the subject has a consistent advantage over the object in terms of performance. It implies that the subject's capabilities, skills, or methods are superior to those of the object, resulting in better outcomes or results.

Predicate-achieve.label: achieve
